{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3566757,"name":"Layton","username":"LaytonK737","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/l/aca169/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-24T12:45:29.525Z","cooked":"

My team has no vision except a simple camera and with this we struggled a lot at our first district is there a way to turn a simple camera into a Apriltag reader or is there some sort of strategy teams use to line up with no vision processing power?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-03-24T12:45:29.525Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":459,"readers_count":458,"score":136.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":496692,"topic_slug":"how-teams-with-a-simple-camera-are-lining-up-with-reef","display_username":"Layton","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64705,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-teams-with-a-simple-camera-are-lining-up-with-reef/496692/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3566781,"name":"Mike","username":"Mike_FRC_56","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mike_frc_56/{size}/178961_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-24T13:13:59.358Z","cooked":"

What do you mean by “simple camera”? Just a USB webcam plugged into the RoboRio?

One low tech solution (if you are using swerve drive) is to create commands that strafe your robot side-to-side at a slow speed - possibly using the bumpers of a controller. Left bumper strafes left, right bumper strafes right. Plug the USB cam into the Rio and show the video stream on the Dashboard. Drive up to the reef so your bumper is flush against it and you can use the camera to see if you’re lined up. If not, move the robot side to side using that button that moves you slowly. You don’t get fine control using the normal swerve drive joysticks, so going at a set, slow speed may work best

In that case, you are using your eyes and brain to line up using a visual cue like the April tag. The next step would be to use some sort of vision processing to mimic that. If you target is to the left, the robot execute that same and and moves to the left once the target is in front no more movement is needed.

From there, you can get more complicated like making your sideways speed proportional to how far away the target is from where you want to be. You can have the robot slowly drive forward while this code is adjusting your sideways speed and then this way you could track into the tag and not have to drive up to it first

All of that work with vision processing is pretty challenging to do in the middle of the built season if you’ve never done it before. If you just want to stream a camera to your dashboard, you can follow these instructions. Vision on the RoboRIO — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-03-24T13:13:59.358Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":435,"readers_count":434,"score":107.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":496692,"topic_slug":"how-teams-with-a-simple-camera-are-lining-up-with-reef","display_username":"Mike","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/vision-processing/roborio/index.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Vision on the RoboRIO — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50093,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-teams-with-a-simple-camera-are-lining-up-with-reef/496692/2","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3566800,"name":"evanperryg","username":"evanperryg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/evanperryg/{size}/259696_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-24T13:44:05.416Z","cooked":"

I’d guess OP is referring to those old IP cameras we used back in the retroreflective tape days. I’m sure plenty of teams still have them laying around.

Remember, OP: vision-based alignment doesn’t need to be automatic, and it doesn’t need to be driven by April tags. @Mike_FRC_56 makes a good point - all you really need for this game is slow side-to-side strafing, and a camera pointing at the reef. This sounds asinine, but you could tape a clear plastic sheet to your laptop screen and draw crosshairs on it with a permanent marker. Just make sure the camera feed always fills the same part of the screen!

Mike_FRC_56:

create commands that strafe your robot side-to-side at a slow speed - possibly using the bumpers of a controller

We used the D-pad (on an Xbox-style controller) for this slow, robot-relative translation.

Last year, we had L/R bumper do a slow rotate, which we eliminated this year by making the rotation curve on the right stick more exponential, giving the drivers more slow control over rotation. (The same wouldn’t work for translation as the left stick is field-relative translation.)

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-03-24T17:09:20.103Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":164,"readers_count":163,"score":32.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":496692,"topic_slug":"how-teams-with-a-simple-camera-are-lining-up-with-reef","display_username":"Michelle Banas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":64705,"username":"LaytonK737","name":"Layton","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/l/aca169/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65540,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"RI, CSA, FTAA | 2403M/3062A"},"post_url":"/t/how-teams-with-a-simple-camera-are-lining-up-with-reef/496692/9","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3567417,"name":"Mike","username":"Mike_FRC_56","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mike_frc_56/{size}/178961_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-24T21:42:22.058Z","cooked":"

One time we were having issues in the middle of a competition so we took a piece of electrical tape and placed it on the screen of the laptop. You knew we were lined up when the target on the field was touching that tape.

It’s not stupid if it works

I’m not familiar with the CTRE code, but they should have something in there to manually set robot-relative speeds. You would create a command that when you press a button, instead of listening to the joysticks, it moves the robot chassis to one side at a given speed. When you let go of the button, it stops executing that command and goes back to listening to the joysticks.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-03-24T21:42:22.058Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":107,"readers_count":106,"score":36.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":496692,"topic_slug":"how-teams-with-a-simple-camera-are-lining-up-with-reef","display_username":"Mike","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50093,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-teams-with-a-simple-camera-are-lining-up-with-reef/496692/10","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3567705,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-25T02:11:55.744Z","cooked":"

There is a WPILib example vision program to detect AprilTags and I added the pose determination using WPILib classes. It runs on a roboRIO but slowly. No good for a roboRIO 1, I’m sure, but might work on a roboRIO 2.

If you just need the detections that takes about 40% of the roboRIO 1. The pose calculation takes about another 40%. The roboRIO 2 is much faster than a roboRIO 1 and you might be able to do both detections and pose but I don’t have a roboRIO 2 to benchmark. Expect the pose calculation to be jittery past a meter or so from the tag.

I have a sample program of my vision experiments. It’s not neat; it’s a sandbox. You can use an IP camera or USB camera with the WPILib Camera Server that it uses.

github.com

SirLanceABot/Classes/blob/master/Classes-Java/VisionAprilTag/Robot.java

// Copyright (c) FIRST and other WPILib contributors.
// Open Source Software; you can modify and/or share it under the terms of
// the WPILib BSD license file in the root directory of this project.


/**
 * This is a demo program showing the detection of AprilTags. The image is acquired from the USB
 * camera, then any detected AprilTags are marked up on the image, transformed to the robot on
 * the field pose and sent to the dashboard.
 *
 * Be aware that the performance on this is much worse than a coprocessor solution!
 * 
 * This example includes an estimated latency time from the time the image appears through to
 * the end of processing the robot pose.
 * 
 * The latency of acquiring the image from the camera mostly depends on the fps setting
 * of the camera, the shutter is global or where the object is if progressive scan.
 * Timing starts before the frame grab statement and that appears to account for much
 * of the camera latency at least for the LifeCam.
 *
